snippet: A dearth of information makes it difficult to document the precise relationship between routine antibiotic use in animals and antibiotic-resistant infections in people, scientists say.
abstract: Scientists say there is a troubling dearth of hard data on the relationship between routine antibiotic used in animals and antibiotic-resistant infections, despite consumer advocates' contentions that there is overwhelming epidemiological evidence linking the two; eighty percent of the antibiotics sold in the United States are consumed by farm animals, yet producers of meat and poultry are not required to report how they use the drugs.
lead_paragraph: A dearth of information makes it difficult to document the precise relationship between routine antibiotic use in animals and antibiotic-resistant infections in people, scientists say.

headline.seo: Use of Antibiotics in Animals Raised for Food Defies Scrutiny
headline.main: Farm Use of Antibiotics Defies Scrutiny
headline.print_headline: Farm Use of Antibiotics Defies Scrutiny
